content: I know the import operation will import information but my question is will the result be what I want? The material I exported from the original Thunderbird was just the files contained in the profile folder - not the folder itself.
creator: info9493

content: Yes, you can import the old profile. The menu process is tools>import>import from another thunderbird installation and then select the desired profile. When you created the backup on the USB drive, thunderbird was NOT to be running. If it had been, the profile may be incomplete.
creator: davidsk

content: highlight the mailng list and rightclick - LDIF is also an option
creator: davidsk

content: Kindly be more specific and detailed: please provide step-by-step instructions for carrying out the operations you have recommended. BTW, from my experience, LDIF is an easier format to export and import than CSV.
creator: groucho3

content: True enough, but you can export them as csv files and then import to the other PC.
creator: davidsk

content: My first suggestion is to include your full email address in both places. That is, include the @ and domain name
creator: davidsk

content: Well, you could initiate a search in the trash folder if there are many messages there. Filters are a strong tool in Thunderbird and I encourage you to become familiar with them.
creator: davidsk
